Name: Benjamin M
Story:
As some know here, I decided to go and get a "real job" like my wife had been "suggesting".

"You know, a W-2. No, I don't care if you don't want to flip burgers! 

Well, I thought that I was doing pretty well driving Uber (after expenses, still about what I earned as a paramedic) but my 2018 Civic hit 70k and gas prices are through the roof.

So, "real job".

Back to EMS? Still a maybe. But I'm not in my 20s anymore, a touch of PTSD, and two hernias.

Back to programming? Competitive, also for the young, and I do not want to be behind a desk.

Law enforcement? That was on my horizon before we moved to the big city and "stuff" happened.

So, one night, I decided to send a Facebook message to a limousine company that I first noticed before I started rideshare full time, brand new to the city life. Instant reply, I was hired on the spot two days later.

First vehicle I drove was a Chrysler 300. Brakes were shot. Second, another 300, tires were bald and one had an enormous chunk of rubber missing.

Soul searched for about three days (and posted here). Decided to give them the benefit of doubt, just as I would want, emailed them basically saying that they are awesome but I can't drive unsafe shit.

Owner's girlfriend stepped in, took care of everything like a boss, and I am now driving their best. The pandemic nearly killed their business, that section of the fleet is just now becoming more in demand.

Now, Winifred. She had just become a regular when I started - very "well to do". First trip was from an independent care facility (now assisted living unit, she's not happy) to the afternoon Mass.

I was warned in advance (and given a salute by her last driver) before I headed to pick her up - third trip for the company. Very demanding pax and she needs a lot of help getting in and out of the car.

She asked me to do five things at once, said she's old enough to be my grandmother (Mom's her age), AC was either too hot or too cold, and made me pull over to find the right radio station. All in the first five minutes 😂

First time waiting for a pax on the job. People were commenting on the fancy car parked by the door to the church. It was her first Mass since the pandemic began.

After I got her situated in the car again, she started to apologize for how she acted before. I cut her off. Told her that I know chronic pain when I see it (arthritic, obese) and how it can definitely **** with your mood. And I told her to stop calling herself old.

Dropped her off, called the company, and told them that if Winifred ever needs a ride to PLEASE let me know. And she requested me for her next trip.

Mass again yesterday, this time I joined her. Boss asked if we needed to charge extra for an escort. 😂

And that's my Sunday moving forward. Paid a decent amount to drive a friend (Winifred said I'd better not think of her as a pax) to church and back.

Oh, and here I am picking up her phone off of the road yesterday because I put it on the roof and forgot. Not a scratch. Divine intervention??😳




Rideshare has been either extremely profitable here or less than minimum wage, just seems to be how the wind blows. Tips are pretty much unheard of, pick up distance is still pretty high for most pings. Pax are still left stranded at our airport.

Even though I'm not totally down with it (seems a bit low), I earn $10/hr from when I leave the "garage" (that can be home if the car isn't needed before or between trips) until I return.

unlike Uber and Lyft, tips are included, minimum of 18% - and many fares are $200+. So, no dead miles and no expenses. Lately driving a 2019 Lincoln MKT, 2017 Continental, 2019 Suburban, and soon a 2020 Continental.

Pax run the gamut, from Winifred to newlyweds, executives, flight crews (airport to hotel and back), organ transplant teams, and - last week - a show creator for AMC followed by his lead actor.

I was star struck enough, then had the surreal experience of the main man behind the show asking me to stop so he could literally run a block to an ATM so he could tip me $20 cash (in addition to the $20 or so included, short airport run).

In conclusion, companies like this are hiring. "Oh, rideshare drivers are un employable" - bullshit. I submitted a resume, showed up on time wearing a suit, "here's where the keys are, water bottles are over there, when can you start" - that was the interview.

So, if you are burnt out being an "ant" (hate that term but whatever), consider the option. And I'm part time for now, still "anting" on and off.

Name: _Tron_
Story:
Uber badly wants me to drive again. It keeps sending incentive notices to my inbox. So as it happens I have been driving. Since last in the saddle I have lost Gold status, and my ability to see the destination of a ride request is now based upon the newish accepting 5 of 10 ride requests algo.

On the surface, the 5-of-10 algo seems to me like a halfway decent compromise, giving drivers up front details if they simply maintain a 50% acceptance rate. Of course drivers who accept a smaller percentage of rides will note that the low pay makes the 5-of-10 algo a joke. But even in my locale, where Uber still pays 98 cents a mile and 17 cents a minute, the 5-of-10 algo is a clown act. As anyone who has focused on the algo knows, acceptance rate is based upon each individual ride request, rather than on passenger request.

The downside of this nuanced difference played out for me yesterday with "Darren". Darren wanted a ride. Badly. His request for a long ride on the Lyft platform came to me, and I declined it. For my own good reasons I was unable to accommodate a pax who wanted a ride out of town. After all, I am an Independent Contractor and it is my right to choose which rides work for me. Darren then came in on the Uber app, which I also declined, lowering my 9 of 10 acceptance rate one notch. Undaunted, for the next half hour Darren toggled back and forth between platforms, requesting his out-of-town ride.

Uber, in all its wisdom, kept sending me Darren's requests. The algo was too dumb to realize that if I turned the request down once, nothing was going to change 5 minutes later. But the requests kept coming, and I noticed my acceptance rate was dropping with each successive decline. Finally, while on another ride, Darren's request came in again. Only this time there was no destination. I didn't realize the request was from stubborn Darren, and stupidly accepted it.

I drive the 10 minutes to the pickup point, then down a 1/4 mile dirt road, which cakes the back of my freshly washed car with dust, only to realize after starting the ride that my pax was the now infamous Darren. "Darren, I'm so sorry. I can't drive you to xxx. I know there's not a lot of Uber cars on duty right now (being that a lot of drivers are still preferring UI) but I just can't do it". Darren, whose family is just starting up a pot farm, replies in a most mellow way that it is totally cool, and to just drop him back to his pickup location. I do and move on.

Uber. Dude. I just want a reasonable driving experience. Anything less than that and you are de-incentivizing me. Get it?






And by the way, cancelling 2 out of 96 rides is a 2.13% cancellation rate. Not the 3% you are showing on my account.

Name: Cvillegordo
Story: We have been having promotions every day, $6 per ride, so our small downtown area where the promotion applies is flooded with drivers. You can sit around and wait for one of the promo rides, or, if you want to make money, you can take what comes your way and hopefully a few of the very short $10 rides will come your way as well. Yesterday I took a 20 minute pick up at our airport for a 20 minute ride. Normally and especially during these promotions I get in touch with the rider and make sure that he is coming back towards the downtown area. 90% of the time that would be the case; if they say they're going North or West towards Harrisonburg I would probably cancel. I don't want to end up 45 minutes away from the downtown area and possibly deadhead all the way back. In this case I got no answer on my text, and assuming that the guy was probably waiting for his bag or just on the phone I went ahead to the pick up anyway. Surprise! Going north to Ruckersville. S.hit!! Oh well. Took him home, $22 ride and $5 tip, OK. Set destination back to downtown and luckily got two trips along the return, one short and one all the way back downtown. Both of these tipped, feeling lucky and good at this point. Then I got the phone call. My airport passenger thinks he left his phone in my car. I look around the back and there it is under the seat on the side where he dropped it. (His girlfriend is smoking hot, and not shy by the way. Kids, this is why you should lock your phones.) So I made the honest and well intentioned mistake of telling him that I found it. This nice guy with the hot girlfriend immediately turned into an entitled jerk and demanded that I return "my property!" to him at his house, which is now more than 45 minutes away from my location. At this point I had already accepted another trip so I told him to call me back in half an hour. A few minutes later I got in touch with support and they confirmed to me that since I had informed the passenger and Uber that I found his property, I was now obligated to return it to him. Good Lord, what a freaking nightmare. Surge popping up on top of the promotion in the downtown area, it's heating up as people are starting to return to their hotels and homes from going out to eat, I'm going to miss making some really good money if I drive all the way out to this dude's house again. He calls me again for the 4th time. He is getting upset and is very pushy, continues to demand that I drive to his home and return his property. I push my luck and fib; tell him that I cannot possibly drive all the way to Ruckersville as "I'm at the end of my shift." After a near meltdown he acquiesces and agrees to meet me half way. I suggest Walmart and he finally agrees. Walmart is fortunately much farther for him than for me, so I came out OK on this. Drove to Walmart did a little shopping, met the guy in front, returned his phone and he didn't say a word; no "thank you!" nothing. What a jerk, and lesson learned; never again will I admit to finding a phone from a distant drop off and never again will I drop anyone off at a distance without thoroughly checking around the back seat. After over 5,000 trips I know better, this was a stupid mistake. But I got my $15 returned item fee, and after another long talk with support they also added a bonus $6 promotion to my account.

Name: Haanjo
Story:
I picked up an Uber Eats order from a discount restaurant.

As I'm about to arrive at the customers apartment, a phone call comes in. I figure it's the customer who wants to give me special instructions to get to their place, so I answer.

Turns out it's the restaurant manager. He said he was not watching the front desk, and his employee forgot to give me the drinks that went with the order.

I tell him to refund the drinks, and I'm not coming back because I don't get paid to go back and deliver the drinks, and besides, it's his employee's responsibility to give me the correct order.

He tells me its between the customer and Uber, and its my responsibility to get the order right too. I tell him not only was his employee rude, but not to blame me for his employees mistake.

He tells me to tell the customer that I forgot his drinks. I tell him I'm done talking to him, to have a good night, and hang up the phone. At this point, I'm pretty irritated, and basically had already raised my voice when he blamed me for the mistake.

Yeah, I know, I could have checked for drinks, but when an employee hands me an order, I'm going to assume its correct. Every once in a while I do check orders for drinks, and occassionally I do catch errors, but I'm not going to waste my time and check the accuracy of orders everytime, especially if 97% of the time the orders are correct anyway, which is my satisfaction rate after this order.

What I didn't realize until I hung up, is that the restaurant can actually give you negative feedback, and when I checked my rating for deliveries, sure enough, the manager dinged me. Apparently the customer dinged me too...about 5 minutes after I checked my rating from the merchant, my customer satisfaction rating had dropped from 98% to 97%...which I suspect happened when the customer called the restaurant and the manager blamed me for the mistake.

Anyway, I came really close for telling the manager to F*** Off, so I'm glad I kept my cool. 

So, if you ever find yourself of the situation, first off, don't be an idiot like me and answer your phone like I did, and if you do answer the phone, be careful what you say to the store manager. Having said that, you aren't a store employee, and if they try to blame you for their employee screwing up, tell them to shove it, because at the end of the day, it's on them and not you.

Name: Haanjo
Story:
Dear Ridershare Passengers,

When I'm waiting for you, I will wait 5 minutes. Not 5 minutes and one second. 5 minutes is 5 minutes. I only get paid roughly 12.5 cents per minute of wait time, and while I'm waiting for you, I'm missing out on other rides. 

And don't say you will tip me extra because often people who say that don't tip at all. For the record, sometimes I get paid more for cancelling the ride than I do for the ride itself, and keep in mind, I'm often parked in an odd spot waiting for you, sometimes blocking traffic, and sometimes dealing with drunk idiots who are trying to steal your ride.

And for the record, I understand that sometimes you need to pay your tab at the bar before you can leave. I get that. But you had a 15 minute notice for me to get there, while I was finishing up my last ride, plus another 5 minute notice while I was on my way to pick you up after dropping off my last passenger.

So, there is no excuse to not be waiting at the curb when I pull up. And for the record, when I started doing rideshare three and a half years ago, I used to bend over backwards for my passengers like you. But often, five minutes would turn into ten minutes, and when I bent over backwards for my passengers the most, you would be a bad passenger, things would go terribly wrong on the ride, and you would give me a one star rating for my efforts.

Over 11,000 rides later, I've learned from riders like you. 

When you say stuff like,

"Be right there",

What you really mean is that you are going to be late. And if I've been patient enough to wait for you for the entire 5 minutes and beyond, no, you can't smoke a cigarette before we leave...get in the freaking car!

So there you have it. I'd like to be a nice guy and wait, but you need to show some courtesy and respect for your driver, and not sit there and socialize with your friend up until the last possible second, because once I hit the gas pedal and start to take off, it's too late, and yelling at me to come back isn't going to change things.

And for the record, it took something like 8,000 rides with 800 late passengers to develop this attitude.  Bottom line is I'm not messing around anymore. So be ready!

Love, 

Your Driver............Vrrrooooooom!

In the first I had a Uber passenger and in the second I was in route to pick up a rider. There was no medical involved. Uber's deductible is $1000 and mine is $500. My insurance sent me a check for $500. Now my 4th vehicle, a hybrid, 2016, I used in the winter months, trying to travel up steep hills covered in Ice and snow. The hybrid constantly shifted from gas to electric and back putting excessive  strain on the combustion engine. Bottom line, I burned out the engine,,,Kaput, Finito, gone. I had the car towed to the dealer to confirm my worst thought...the engine was DOA. The dealer mentioned that there was a recall on this particular model year...the bearings were wearing unnecessarily fast. The dealer contacted the Hyundai factory . . their email to the dealer was very short and sweet. GIVE THE CUSTOMER A NEW ENGINE...AT NO CHARGE.
Now I have a 2016 vehicle with 180,000 miles and a new engine. My total mileage, from pickup to drop off and drop off to pickup in 2020 was 156,000 miles.

Name: #1husler
Story:
Pax have been holding court, talking smack and spilling the tea (so to say) about all the kinds of drivers they really don't like, and why they give one stars and complaints. 

Here are some most common categories pax seem to talk about:

1. The odd-ball. Sure, it goes without saying that RS would attract its share of society's outliers (ie, those who need to pay the bills but can't manage a W-2 gig), but some seem to take it one step beyond, to the point of turning off, or even freaking out pax. Stand out examples, according to pax, include one guy who had a pit bull riding shotgun (service dog? who knows???), a woman who kept addressing a male pax as "Martha" (even after he corrected her) and another lady who had the inside of her car decked out with pulsing disco lights. 

2. The maniac on the streets. Its one thing to drive like a "bat out of hell" to hustle to the drop off ASAP, but completely another to almost cause multiple accidents, get into an unsparring amount of altercations (both verbal and physical) with other drivers on the road until pax pleads to end the ride early and be let off at the nearest corner. Not good for "The Community"!

3. The slob. No pax likes getting into stranger's car which looks (and smells) like a junk yard. Even if their own car is that way or worse, they won't tolerate it when "Ubering" or "Lyfting"... pax complain the some drivers car get super gross, and they have roll the windows because of the funky odor....drivers grouse about pax eating in their cars, but a number of drivers (as reported by pax) are the one's munching away, with a sandwich and/or burrito in hand, while driving, food slipping everywhere. Clearly a one star ride there. 

4. The anti-social introvert. Many of us (yours truly included) remain open to talking shop with a pax, about this and that, to establish rapport to pull down a tip. So it's surprising how many drivers don't work that tip, and instead simply unlock the door, set the GPS and drive in total silence, arrive, unlock door, done...no greeting and welcome, confirmation of name and destination, "how's it going?" etc, nothing. And I'm not talking about members of the Deaf Community who are driving...I mean the folks who take the whole "our job is just to just to drive pax from point A to point B" ethos a bit too literally. One pax recounted how they get into the car, told her driver "good morning" and received a grunt as a response, followed by glowering stare through the mirror. She canceled the ride (I might have too). 

Do any of you fill into these groups?

Or?

Can anyone add to this list?

Actually, it was more like 35 seconds...

Last night I had a Lyft pickup at a pool (billiards) bar at around 12:30 am.

After about a minute and a half of waiting, a guy comes out and says, "Wow, you were fast", not realizing he had been in my que for close to 25 minutes, and was less than 2 miles from my last drop off. He then goes back into the bar.

At around the 4 minute mark, he comes back out and says he is waiting for his friend, and proudly says he will make it worth my while if I wait. I simply respond with the universal "ok, ok". At that point I explain to him that he has about 30 seconds...and he runs into the bar to get his friend.

The clock ticks down to zero, and he still hasn't shown up, so naturally I bolt. With around 11,000 Uber and Lyft rides to date, I no longer mess around. I'm serious when I say you have 30 seconds...

I recently had an interview for a driving job. One of the questions posed by the interviewer was:

"At a junction with a four way stop sign, four cars arrive at their respective stop signs at the same time. Who has the right of way."

"Nobody", I replied

"Incorrect", replied the interviewer. "The correct answer is the driver to your right.

"Incorrect", I replied. "If four cars arrive at the same time, then each car is to the right of another driver, meaning that all cars have right of way which, in turn, means that none of them does - none would have more right than any of the three drivers do.

"That's what the California drivers' handbook says", said the interviewer.

"Then, in this case, the handbook is wrong", I replied.

When I arrive at the same time as another vehicle at a multi-way stop sign:

- If the other driver is in a BMW or Audi, then the driver will believe (s)he automatically goes first, so I just let them.

- Any other driver, they will usually hesitate and dawdle, resulting in a Mexican standoff. I hit the gas and go.

Me: Ok, I see...we're going around the corner there?

Pax: I know, its only 3 blocks, but I didn't feel like walking home from work today

Me: Oh cool. Do you usually "Uber" because home and work then?

Pax: Not always, I walked to work this morning, but I just feel too lazy to do it this afternoon, so....

Both these ride were fine with me...because this PUs were each only like 3 mins away from me and I was chasing down promos on them (I knocked out these rides in under 5 mins total)....but aside from that it seems a waste during an "Uber shortage" to take lazy pax 3 blocks down the road to get a beer while others need to go to the airport, etc., and are getting a "no car available" response...I'm wondering if Uber would hike minimum fares (AND share it with drivers) during this so-called "driver shortage" to better utilize drivers.

Name: MyJessicaLS430
Story:
Yesterday afternoon, I drove back home during lunch break. Ahead of me was a brand new ES with a temporary plate whose driver was waiting for somebody to open the building main gate. Obviously the driver doesn't live here as he walked toward me and signalled that he was picking up somebody. He is an older gentleman in the late 50s and politely asked if I could buzz him in. Sure. I needed to get inside too 🤣 . 

The first thing I realized is his hat that reads US Marine. Out of curiosity, I asked whether he was still actively serving (may be a position of command, intelligence or training the newly recruits, etc). By the time I entered the passcode, he said he no longer served and was no different than any other citizen. Then I thought we would part our ways after a simply reply with "Oh, I see". When I was about to leave, the same car was still parking by the garage gate with hazard lights on. I then offered to open the garage gate beside the main gate such that he could wait inside the building. He said "That is sweet of you but I don't know which floor my  lives".

Wait a second, did he say ? "Sorry, by any chance are you driving Uber or Lyft?", I asked. Later, he told me that it was the second week doing rideshare as a means of distraction from the pain of losing his daughter to TNBC (triple negative breast cancer). "I am so sorry for the loss, I know how hard it is to accept the reality of tested negative for all the receptors". Before I answered his question about my background, I thought it was far more important for him to learn how not to be taken advantage of. "Sir, I know this is not my business but I think you should shuffle and move on. It has already been almost 15 minutes since we first met. You should have cancelled the ride". Personally I despise any behaviours that abuses the older generations. Unlike the cunning, deceitful and entitled youth, the elder adults are honest and hard-working humans. They don't deserve to be treated like this. 

After leaving him confused, I disclose that I am a former driver. This just gets to my nerves how his kindness is abused. I left him my contact if he wanted a rideshare 101. Yes, that may sound ignorant to be rideshare mentor as I am nowhere close to how experienced most are on this forum but again, he deserves better than this. At this paltry rate, these low-lives do not deserve a brand new vehicle, not to mention a Lexus. "Allow me to be blunt but you are not going to make money. You are basically giving people free rides". Although I realize that this is just an activity to keep him occupied, it doesn't make any financial sense in any part.

Name: Aw Jeez
Story:
I read posts on this forum and I get the impression that some of you really don't this job and really don't like our customers. And I always want to ask: Why do you do this? By now, everyone should realize that Uber is not a great full-time job - if it ever was. By now, you can't exactly blame Uber for your particular situation. You've had plenty of time to re-evaluate and get out if that's what you want. And so, again I wonder: Why keep doing something you so obviously dislike?

Middle-aged couple got in the car at a hotel the other morning. Black couple but I don't think it matters. Woman asks me to pop the truck, so I do and then I hop out and help them load their numerous bags. As we leave for the short ride to the airport, I ask them about their stay and such. Just idle chit-chat. When we get to the airport, I hop out and go get one of the little baggage carts they provide. This ain't New York, it's pretty chill here and I didn't have another ride stacked.

"You're the best Uber driver ever!" the old guy goes. Which I know is not true, but he meant it sincerely. "Our last two drivers ignored us...wouldn't help with the bags, didn't talk to us...made us feel like we were imposing on him." I thanked them and wished them a pleasant trip home. By the time I was out of the airport, I saw the $10 tip on top of the $5.71 fare.

Look, this job really isn't that hard or that bad. Just be nice to people...treat them like human beings, not some big inconvenience or annoyance. If you don't like people, perhaps ride-sharing is not the field for you. If you're not making enough money doing ride-share, perhaps it's not the field for you. And if you resent passengers for not living up to your expectations at the beginning, middle or end of the ride, perhaps ride-share is not the field for you.

Me, I happen to love this job! Every day, I thank God that Uber came along and got me out of driving a taxi (which was okay but a lot more work for the money). I've had a lot of fun jobs...but mainly I've been a helicopter pilot most of my life, and doing  job is the most fun I've ever had. No, I'm not getting rich, and I'm putting about 30,000/year on the car, which is fine. Uber/Lyft gives me about $2,400 - $2,500 per month in my bank account. I could make more if I wanted to work harder, but I don't.

Some of you guys really need an attitude check. The passengers are not your enemy. I wish some drivers would stop treating them as though they are. It makes it hard for the rest of us.

Name: Benjamin M
Story:
Already depressed, stressed out, and getting fatigued running all over the place for awful pings (ENDLESS after starting a trip), I accepted a ping 16 minutes away back downtown from far south in a bad area. At least it would get me back to the city. The ping only said "premium pickup possible" with a $2 surge.

Driving there, I saw that it was a hospital pick up for a patient. These have been prevalent lately, especially at JenCare Senior Clinics. I did not think much of it, usually they're fairly short, but a tip is out of the question because they're booked by a third party. 

I pull up, patient is wheeled to my car, and belongings are put in the trunk. Then I slide "start". 

198 mile trip. Already hungry and tired, EZ Pass running low, and no compensation for 190+ miles to get home. 

I turn to the door to hopefully grab the staff, they vanished into thin air. Called from the app, went to the patient. 

Apologized to him profusely and escorted him to a bench in front of the door. I tried to explain that he would need to tell the hospital that he needed another car and to let the driver know in advance that it was an extremely long trip. He did not seem to understand that, but did understand why I had to cancel. 

Medical staff and patients often seems to think that all we do is medical transport if we pick up at a hospital or clinic. They do not understand that we're Joe Regular Uber Driver. 

And it's very frustrating, especially after years of doing actual medical transport - including trips such as this, but being paid almost $30/hr regardless of dead miles, driving a vehicle that doesn't belong to me, and not paying for fuel or tolls. 

I really hope he got a ride somehow. And flipping the bird to Uber for not indicating that this was a 40+ minute trip.

Name: Aw Jeez
Story:
When I switched from taxi driver to R/S, I got a lot of grief from some former cabbie friends. But as the taxi industry in my city evaporated, one of my major critics wisely decided to switch over too. He turned in his leased cab, bought a little Chevy four-door, and signed up with Lyft (but  Uber for some reason).

He did Lyft for a couple of weeks - enjoyed the money-in versus expenses-out. This past Monday, I texted him and asked how his weekend went? "Great!" he said. "I made $315 on Saturday and Sunday." I thought that was pretty good, because Saturday was so rainy that I didn't even drive. Then he added, "But I made all of that delivering food. I don't even do Lyft anymore. Too much driving!"

And there you have it. Uber and Lyft could not have predicted the rise in food-delivery services, and the need for them during this pandemic (which will continue). Bottom Line: Food delivery drivers make more money with less miles driven. They stay local, and don't go on any long trips like I did today:  trips over to Alabama with a deadhead back because I cannot take Uber  Lyft trips trips in Alabama.

I strongly suspect that more and more R/S drivers are switching to food for the same reason(s) as my friend. And so I am not surprised that Uber and Lyft have gotten super-busy here in my town, where it used to be pretty slow. Me? I'll stick with passengers. The numbers are okay by me, and I don't want to deliver food.

She talked price on the phone and then hung up. We then started talking, and she said she was going deeper into the south side of Chicago to "complete a deal". She clutched her large purse and counted cash. I thought for sure it was something else, but I found out that she had human hair wigs in her purse.

She said this when I asked her how she is managing the pandemic with all the uncertainty in employment for everyone (This is one of my standard pax questions). She said, like many young pax, that she was self-employed, and bought and sold hair weaves and wigs. She explained that all her products come straight from Asia. She said, "It comes from your countries, China, Korea, and India." 

She said that the best hair and prices come from the East. She buys them from a secret source and then resells them. This is why she feels the need to hide them from law enforcement. "Human hair" wigs are not by themselves illegal, but she felt that if law enforcement somehow discovered the source, she could get into trouble (sort of like having cartons of cigarettes which escaped duty/ U.S. Customs/ tax)

When I asked her if I could see one, she looked behind us and around first, said, "Well, I don't see any police, so here is one". She showed me a few, and some were weaves and some were wigs (which one was dyed blond and brown). They looked very nice and high quality to me. The pax described her business, which was booming.

She said that there are smugglers of vast amounts of human hair which are often obtained illegally. She said that in some Asian countries, ladies have their long hair cropped off against their will, sometimes in cases of religious sacrifice (like when a "holy" leader will tell the lady that to show her love and devotion to a god, then she must demonstrate a sacrifice...like her long hair. (Which the religious leader will then sell). 

I didn't really know this illegal, but I guess the young lady knew that she cannot be in possession of large quantities of it. This puzzled me, because I know many wigs are made with real human hair, and I had no idea this would be illegal. She really acted like she had bags of illicit substances in her purse, which was my first guess. I am guessing that while a person can have maybe one of two wigs for personal use, if someone has many many such hair pieces, then it may not be permitted if it was determined that such products were smuggled into the U.S.? 

I suppose I found this pax ride interesting, because she told me that up to 90% of young ladies on the south and west sides of Chicago have wigs and hair extensions! I thought that young ladies just straighten their hair and then carefully take hours to "weave" them or braid them by hand. But my pax explained that almost always you are looking at a wig, not their natural hair. 

Then she surprised me by pulling up her own beautiful weave to reveal... a nearly bald shaved head! My first pax of this Sunday night was a guy I drove from Glenview, IL to downtown Chicago. He previously worked in the advertising business but was laid off due to covid. Now, he just started trying to make a living rehabbing houses and flipping them. On the long ride (35 minutes), we talked about a lot of things but mostly he complained about Uber and Lyft these days. He said that he and his friends were "die hard rideshare loyalists", but recently he started souring on both companies.

For example, he said that tonight (Easter Sunday), he could not get a Lyft or an Uber for over an hour until I accepted the ride. I drove 15 minutes to pick him up. Before I accepted the ride, he said that both Uber and Lyft told him some message like, "No drivers in your area, try again soon" or "Are you sure you wish to request, limited available cars"...something like that. He was so grateful that I finally picked him up, because he was just about to give up. He told me, "If you hadn't come, then I would have had to stay overnight with my ex-wife, so thank from the bottom of my heart for that!" 

He mentioned the ridiculous surge. Lately, he said the prices for both Uber and Lyft were equal or sometimes a lot more than what a taxi used to be. And.... there were no more quick pickup times (5 minutes or less) that he was used to for rideshare. Now, just like the taxi industry before, he would often wait up to an hour (as he was in the suburbs), for an Uber or Lyft to show...or "none available"...just like the taxis.

Therefore, he voiced active hope that the taxi industry would get themselves back together to shape and make a valiant comeback. We discussed how the Chicago medallions were a high of $385,000 back in 2013. Now, there is no bid... (no buyers). So he hoped that now that the prices are so incredibly low, there could be a chance for the "left for dead" taxicab companies to make a comeback...and wished eagerly for them to make an effort.

This got me thinking...

I was actually far happier for a multitude of reasons driving a taxi (part time I drove for Flash Cab and other companies) than driving rideshare for two very evil companies... I felt I had very more control over my destiny driving a cab. Plus, I paid zero attention to whether my car would depreciate, not have to worry that I could be "deactivated" for a nonsense complaint, etc. etc. etc. etc. etc.

What if?.....

Name: Aw Jeez
Story:
In another thread, Benjamin M talks about how few drivers seem to be out there. Seems that way here in my town too (Pensacola, FL). A lot of people have suggested reasons - and maybe some of them are valid. Here's what I know...

I turn the Lyft app on first because it's less "fussy" than the stupid Uber app. ("Take a picture of yourself." Then, "Now take a picture with your mask on." And then, "Now give us a urine sample." It never ends!) Before I can even get Uber up and running, the Lyft app is sending me a trip. From that point on, it's go-go-go, stacked pings all day for as long as I want to drive. Yes, some of them are for far-away pickups and I decline as many of them as I can. Many days I don't even log-on to Uber.

I hear from a lot of passengers that they have loooong wait times, and sometimes they get a message that no cars are available. Damn! I had one passenger tell me how hard it was for him to get a driver to pick him up, as he was enthusiastically thanking me for coming to get him. I said, "Well, it *is* my job, dude." And he goes, "No, no. One driver told me that he doesn't do passengers anymore, he primarily just does food. Says there's more money in it." And I thought: Maybe that's why the passenger apps have been so busy these days - drivers are switching to food so they don't have to deal with...you know...people? May be... Maybe if I was in this for the money, I'd deliver food instead too.

People in general are becoming more and more dependent on ride-share to get around, even in the suburbs where there are typically fewer drivers. Lyft and Uber like to send you (meaning: me) all over hell for pickups. Given the option, I don't accept an Uber or Lyft ping that's over 12 minutes away. But Lyft is sneaky - they'll slide a new ride in when you've just begun the first one. I keep the volume on my phone down, so I don't always hear the, "New standard ride added to queue" announcement. 

I used to work six hours a day to make my "target" revenue. Now I do it in four or five. So I'm kind of with Benjamin M here. I kind of wish there were more drivers out in my town. It's F-ing busy here. And my fear is that the less-satisfied people become with ride-share, the more they'll gravitate back to taxis.

Name: The Gift of Fish
Story:
There are a two points of view regarding post-your-boast earnings threads in which people post their earnings in various levels of detail; posting summaries only, providing full breakdowns of individual trips, or anything and everything in between. Some people say that posting earnings guides to one's own market is foolish. Others, judging by the number of them on here, think that they are great. My own opinion is that they certainly are foolish. However, they have also benefitted me, which seems contradictory. Here is my experience.

Late last year I was browsing this forum when I noticed a post-your-boast thread. "It's HOPPING in my town", posted the OP, who went on to describe in detail the goings-on in his local market. He had posted a screenshot of the driver app screen of his latest weekly earnings broken down by day, and also screenshots of several individual rides showing the spots that the rides originated, along with the day, date, time and value of each one.

"This is interesting", I thought. The area advertised by the earnings boaster is a smallish community around 40 miles outside a major metro area in California, which I knew vaguely. I have friends who live very close to it whom I hadn't seen in a while, plus things had been very slow in the Bay Area. I had also felt like taking a little vacation. So I decided to go and visit, and combine a vacation with a chance to make some good money. I had never driven rideshare there but my plan was simple. I would just go to the spots identified by the OP on the days and times advertised by him, turn on the driver app and wait.

And so it happened. One road trip later, I went to the first staging area, turned the app on and waited. Things turned out to be just as the OP had said. Demand was excellent and I soon bagged some great high-dollar rides, and a couple of very high dollar rides. Over the next week I was very pleased with the results. Interestingly, during this time, I picked up the same passenger three times from her house was a couple of miles from where I was staying, indicating that there were few drivers in the area. This, coupled with the nice surges and excellent ping quantity, was evidence of a very favourable demand:driver ratio in the area.

Now, back to the question posed above, regarding whether post-your-boast is a good idea, for both the poster and for me. Let's find the answer with simple cost:benefit analyses. If the benefits outweigh the costs then we'll say that it was a good result, and if benefits do not outweigh the costs, we'll say that it was not a good result.

For me, the costs of the exercise were gas to get to and from the poster's location, and the earnings I did not make in the Bay Area. The benefits were the earnings I made in his area, which exceeded the gas cost and my foregone home earnings by a country mile. So, for me, it was a good result.

For the OP, it's hard to estimate the costs of me working his area. When I accepted the pings there, I obviously denied those rides to all other drivers in the area. Was the driver one of those drivers? Was he working the area on the days and times I was? There's no way to tell. All we know is that it was possible. It's also possible that I was not the only driver attracted into his area by his advertising. Now, let's look at the other side of the analysis - the benefit side to him of advertising his area. This can be summed up as zero. In dollar terms, $0. Nada. As we said above, if the benefits outweigh the costs, then it is a positive result. However, with a benefit of zero, the benefits of advertising one's own area on a public forum can never, by defintion, outweigh the cost. The cost being, of course, the risk of losing business to competitors that one attracted into the area.

In summary, advertising one's area in post-your-boast threads is foolish, but the magnitude of the foolishness depends on the level of detail given. At the top of the tree, we have posting exact hotspots together with the days of the week and times to get good rides there. This will result in immediate competition from other drivers turning up. Further down the list of self-scuppering is the posting of daily earnings totals and the general location of the earnings. While one does not divulge the exact locations and times of the opportunities, it is still persuasive in attracting drivers, both old and new, into one's area. With zero benefit for the poster boaster, it is hard to see how this is a good idea. As seen above, there is no benefit to it for the advertiser. However, for the driver looking for new opportunities and areas to drive in, or for existing drivers who have taken a break and are considering returning to rideshare in their town, these posts can be golden eggs.

Conclusion - keep posting them, please! Just don't do it in my area. :thumbup:

I asked gently her if she enjoyed his company and the entire arrangement, and she seemed just okay with it. Like she didn't say that she really loved him or that she hated him or anything like that. For her it was just kind of a business arrangement to help her support herself and her young son. Of course she didn't tell me the amount, and obviously I didn't ask but she said that he sends her money every month

I thought this was interesting because during this pandemic people must cope in all sorts of different ways. Name: MyJessicaLS430
Story:
While I have no idea how the glorious days were like when these RS companies first emerged, there is no question that the rates are paltry these days. With the combination of multiple rate cuts, deteriorating passengers and the pandemic, I have decided to quit once and for all.

Recently I have been obsessed with deliveries, most of which are grocery shopping. At first it sounds ridiculous to me to be paid Uber rate to not only transport cargoes but also include the shopping component. Contrary to my expectation, this is very addicting. Don't be mistaken, I am not saying grocery shopping gigs are better than Ubering in any part. Although the base pay is about $6, consider the amount of time needed to complete one delivery, this is certainly not worth the effort without any incentives. What I mean by "incentives" are in nature, not the useless badges and ratings.

First, I love the upfront information about expected pay, time to completion and pick-up and drop-off locations, all of which we are supposed to be entitled to, not to be provided only if certain outrageous criteria are met. Here comes the best part, the monetary incentives. Depending on the local markets and time, the estimated payout (with bonus included) can be far more attractive than doing rides, not to mention you will have full control of where to end up after a delivery. Needless to say, how much we take home is also highly dependent on the willingness of customers to tip. However, if you are the type that withdraw every penny after each delivery, this may not work for you because there is a $500 cap. Personally I have no problem for these companies to keep the money for a year if there is a minimum of 1% interest rate 😂.




Finally, I am also astonished by the real time support. For instance, a transaction will be denied by default when customers request additional items after we accept an order. It only takes a minute or two for the support to override the payment authorization. They are also very helpful to assign a return for unsuccessful deliveries. Since not every store accepts return because of the pandemic, basically I have free food plus the $5 to drive back to the store. The only time that happened to me also include some adult products. Um may be I should consider selling them.

Name: Young Kim
Story:
Weekends are when I get my best stories, and I thought this one was interesting. I picked up a pax named William near the Merchandise Mart train station in downtown Chicago, and we got to discussing the pandemic and how he was dealing with it. He shared with me that just over a year ago, he was let go from the most fun job he ever had. He was working for Yelp! (the company who does the online reviews for restaurants and local businesses). He said that it was by far the most fun he ever had, and he was making great money.

William said that the top salesman for the downtown Chicago office made over $30,000 in commission in a month! before the pandemic crushed business. He said he was one of the top salesman and made six figures. And......he loved the environment. He told me about how there was pre-pandemic nearly 1000 people in the Yelp! downtown office, and after you go through security, it was a job workplace heaven. He gave the funny analogy that the "pit" where everyone was selling was like in the movie "Wolf of Wall Street", and how when someone got a big sale, everyone would know because some "horn" would go off and everyone would go over and congratulate the salesman. (He mentioned though there was no drugs or dwarfs thrown).

The pax told me that there were ping pong tables, other amenities like board games and lounge chairs (to be used during break), and FREE BEER and FREE FOOD! And he said it was very good food, all you can eat. I was surprised because I thought that only like Amazon, Facebook, and Google had this type of workplace amenities. I didn't know Yelp! had that kind of money.

William told me that the company really cared about making employees happy. He said that as the pandemic crushed business, Yelp! tried hard to keep as many people onboard and on payroll. He said that he started working remotely from home, but it was totally soul crushing. After all, restaurants and businesses closed down, and trying to get new clients was darn near impossible, he said.

He said Yelp! paid some bonuses and tried and tried,...but in the end, it was not enough, and he and most everyone was let go. He said there is still a shell left of his team in the downtown Chicago office, and he has no ill will towards his former company because they tried so hard to survive, but the Chicago location collapsed anyhow. After a few months on UI, he found a job with FedEx as a driver, and he was being dropped off in the Niles, IL location (by Touhy ave and Niles Center road). He seemed happy enough as a FedEx employee, and we both discussed that business was BOOMING for FedEx and his job is likely secure as an ironclad chain.

But wistfully, he lamented the loss of the best job he said he ever had in his life....

Name: Young Kim
Story:
On Saturday night at 3:30 am, I had a pickup in Skokie, IL (a north suburb) by AMC Theaters also near Red Robin and Buffalo Wild Wings. I swiped right, and saw the three young men entering my Uber were going to the Hyatt Place in Rosemont, IL, about a 13 minute ride. Immediately I noticed they were drunk, but even more vexing...very loud. They began to ask me many questions, about everything. I answered abruptly with monosyllables. They were loud... ugh. Then, one of them got on their phone and put it on speaker and called some girl. Then they all proceeded to have a group discussion of their night, also asking me questions to try to involve me in their drunken talk. 

It was the end of a long Saturday night, which are always very taxing for an Uber ant. Especially now during the pandemic, it has gotten so very much worse. So I was not in a mood to feign interest with 3 very loud annoying pax who was discussing their hard partying with some girl they all knew. I could hear them talk stuff like, "Yeah, when we sat down on the table and that other group approached I was pissed...", "Don't you think that the promoter will be interested in holding that party for next weekend?"...stuff like that.

So, I put on my Sony "almost" noise cancelling headphones (with very snug earbuds), and turned on some peaceful classical music at a loud volume. I told them that I need to listen to the Uber navigation system to insure that I drive to their destination properly, so I may not be able to communicate with them. Suddenly, as the soft notes of the symphony emerged, the three annoying pax almost seemed to magically disappear from my car. I could hear them still trying to talk to me, gesturing at me, and one even tapped my shoulder trying to get my attention.

I did remove one earbud and asked, "Is there a problem?", and he answered, "No, I just wanna ask you how...(this and that)". I interrupted with, "So sorry, but I need to hear the Uber navigation. It is very important." And then put back on my classical music... 

Soooo nice. It was suddenly like I was in another world of peace and harmony.

I think they got the message, because at the end of the ride, they just got out without saying a word, and I did not say "goodnight" either. I recommend everyone get a pair of very snug blutooth headphones (preferably noise cancelling), which will drown out annoying pax. I am doing this more and more now, with great results.

The only issue of course is that you won't be able to hear other traffic, like someone honking their horn. And most importantly, you must redouble your sight for any emergency vehicles since you won't be able to hear sirens. But....I think that at least for me, it is totally worth it. When an annoying pax is about to test my patience, some Mozart, Beethoven, or Handel will help me immensely.

For myself, I care nothing at all about getting a one star review from the pax if they feel I am ignoring them. If they are loud and obnoxious, I put them on ignore... with great satisfaction and relief.

Name: Young Kim
Story:
Saturday night February 27th was a very unique evening in the sense that I nearly hit one pedestrian, and had to brake rather hard for another (but I saw the latter coming easily). Also, I very regrettably sent a bunny into rabbit heaven. It was strange because I do sometimes have to narrowly avoid clueless pedestrians, but this all happened within a short span of time in one night. The first was the most jarring, because I nearly (without exaggeration) came very close to striking a pax darting out from between two cars into another Uber. (I do just wish to point out that I was not speeding at all, and rather driving about 3-4 miles under the speed limit). 

I was driving southbound on Linder Ave approaching Lawrence Ave in the north side of Chicago, and on a narrow street, when a would be pax literally jumped out from between two cars and ran in front of my car to their Uber across the street. I hit the brake and gasped at how close I came to hitting him/her. After stopping, I saw the other Uber ant's face who was parked look at me ...and we both shook our heads in disbelief. His pax, in a white parka jacket, with fur on the hoodie so I could not see the face, jumped into the Uber, completely not even acknowledging that he/she (I could not tell) almost got seriously injured. The street was 30 mph, so if I did not brake hard, I doubt the pax would have had life threatening injuries, but he/she would have been gravely hurt.

How many of you have had a person sprint in front of your vehicle running for their own Uber?

Next I was driving west on Harrison Street by Halsted next to the UIC campusk a short while later, and I saw a bunny suddenly jump into the street in a hurry. I slammed on the brakes (I was doing an UberEats order so there was no pax in my car), and veered right fast. As the car decelerated quickly, I thought I cleared the bunny easily......but...it jumped back right into my path under my tires in the last split second!

Squirrels (very common) I have avoided easily because they move in a predictable trajectory, and at constant velocity and zero acceleration. Deer are easy to avoid because they are large and move slowly. Geese or birds are even easier because they move either very very slowly or just fly away. But this bunny was moving and darting all over the place! As it jumped into my path, it hopped like up, left, down, and then finally back to my right...just as I thought I missed it. I heard a thud... I felt awful and disgusted, then hoped that it was not the bunny.

I slowly backed up away left from center...but I saw the heap of rabbit lying in the road. I am not sure why that bothered me so much, but I felt really awful. But not guilty. Because I knew that I did everything I could to avoid that bunny. Plus I was as I always am paying close attention to animals. And I was not speeding at all. It was the very first time in my life I hit a bunny, and noted that I could not have predicted its movement, as it seemed in retrospect completely random and unpredictable. Its last jump was right into my tire paths...sigh.

And so surprisingly (because it happened again shortly later), my next pax pickup was further south in the south side of Chicago by Roosevelt Ave and Racine Ave (a rather faster moving bigger street, 35 mph) I saw a man just run across the street in front of my car. However, I saw him running from the sidewalk easily, as his path was not obscured by cars like the first pedestrian I mentioned who appeared suddenly in between two parked cars. I ended up braking hard though, and he slowly just walked in front of my car as I came to a complete stop. I was a bit unhappy that some people just run into the street (even on a busy street) without looking at ALL. 

I am certain that all Uber ants have come close to hitting clueless pedestrians and likely causing roadkill of animals through no fault of their own. But have any of you actually HIT a pedestrian? Please do share your story of near misses...

Name: Young Kim
Story:
All these long hours trying in vain to keep positive are weighing me down... and I can sense darker feelings coming over me. Around 2:00 am, I had a pickup at a bar in the northwest suburbs of Chicago in Arlington Heights. After the pax made me wait (I remember her name was Patricia) for 3 minutes, I saw her come out in a group of 4. I rolled down my window and said, "Sorry, but there is too many people". 

She was clearly drunk, and her face was red. She just stared with glassy eyes for a short while silently, and then said, "Well, can you still take me and my friends home?" 

I said, "Sorry, too many people". (I have a cooler and a bunch of stuff in my front passenger seat)

She replied, "Can't you move the stuff to the trunk?" "I'll tip you".

I replied to her that I could even though it is against Uber policy... but it may be easier for her to order a second Uber...

At this point, she acted all entitled... and she said angrily, "What is wrong with you?!" "Are you OK?" "Are you OK to take us home??!"

I felt something in me snap... (I thought to myself "obviously why the heck would I not be OK? it is you that is not OK because you are an angry drunk!")

I abruptly said to her, :"Hey! I'm cancelling this ride! I did nothing wrong here, and suddenly you are being rude to me. I don't take rude customers". She just stared at me in shock and disbelief... but then I think it dawned on her that she made a mistake. 

I felt such a joy cancelling on her. She did not think this through. Tonight, the wait times, especially in the suburbs, were LONG. Like 15-20 minutes long. And...people were telling me that Ubers were cancelling on them. And the bar she was at with her friends was closing. And, some pax were telling me that they saw the dreaded, "Sorry no UberX's in your area, pls try again later" in the northwest suburbs where I was driving. She may have to wait for 15-20 minutes (or longer), and would have to beg the bar to let her and her friends stay inside until another Uber shows up.

Drunk entitled pax often act in a manner that is completely illogical and detrimental. She probably thought in her drunken state that she could be rude and order the Uber drivers to do whatever she wanted. 

Big mistake... this was not pre-Covd in the middle of downtown Chicago. Her friends who were sober knew instantly the mistake Patricia made, and apologized and asked if I would bring them anyway. 

I said, "No." I knew also that once the ride started, she would complain and give me crap the entire ride, and obviously one star me (which I don't care about), but I didn't want to deal with an angry drunk pax INSIDE my car. I found that if the pax before the ride even starts, sniffs of a problem, it is better to cut your losses... and get out of there.

Name: Young Kim
Story:
This was an interesting ride in the sense that it echoes more or more of what I am experiencing with pax. I picked up a couple of young men in the southwest suburbs of Chicago (Western Springs), and brought them all the way up to the north side of Chicago. In this long ride, I had a lot of time to talk to them. Both were out of school now and wanted to become YouTube, TikTok, Instagram stars. They wanted to make it as recording artists...across social media. They told me that they do livestream feeds where people tune into their work, and as I understood it they mix music, like hip-hop.

Where it became more interesting to me was that they gave up looking for a stable job because the price of Bitcoin was soaring so much, that they felt they will never have to work a real job again for the rest of their lives. I did check after the ride ended, and I just saw it hit around $57,000 per Bitcoin. I feel like the pandemic low last year was around $5,000. They kept telling me that I should invest heavily in it... they spoke of it almost as if it was a new religion. They were talking one million dollars per Bitcoin...and stuff like that.

I heard that Uber may accept Bitcoin as payment...or some rumors of that?

I wished them well, and for their sake I hope that they achieve their dreams. But I wondered to myself if this is the right attitude? Can a plethora of young college age/college graduates decide and become successful cryptocurrency investors... and not have to work any real jobs? 

I am not sure if such an attitude is best. I do own some Bitcoin actually, and I don't recommend it or not recommend it here...but I wanted to share an interesting story about how many young people are banking on the price of it to allow them never to do 9-5 again. I am not so sure if that is a good plan. Even if it works, our economy will still need people to work right?

It started off fine... I picked up 2 pax at a bar in a suburb south of the city around 3:00 am. It was a couple. The guy suddenly started asking me if I was Korean. I replied, "Yes, sir, I am". He proceeded to ask me 27 times exactly if I was Korean on a 17 minute ride. Each time, I would answer "Yes." After around the 20th time, I started counting it back to him. "Yes, I am Korean, that is for the 22nd time"..."Yes, I am Korean, for the 23rd time"..."Yes, I am Korean, for the 24th time" etc. At this point, I went from being annoyed to very amused...

The girlfriend (who was very cute), started to apologize profusely and kept telling her boyfriend to shut up. She was quite friendly and tried to divert the repeated questions to other topics. She asked me if I thought she was fit and cute, showed me her stomach, to which I replied, "Of course!..."haven't you seen a mirror recently?"

Then... the boyfriend suddenly started asking me, " ...are you Korean?" over and over...

I calmly replied that both my parents are Korean, so my genetics followed from that biological fact... He in his drunken state, started to repeat that same question over and over... afraid to get to the 27th time for that question, I cut him off... I then answered by having a short talk about how there are 46 chromosomes in each cell of my body... consisting of 22 pairs, and two sex chromosomes...inheritance patterns, etc. And all this explains why my being Korean has a logical connection to my parents being Korean.

For my own amusement, I quickly pointed out how traits are inherited from each parent through DNA transmission according to Mendelian genetics... and again tried to explain that is the reason I am in fact Korean and not another race...

After a long silent pause... he again asked..."So...why are you Korean?"

I tried so hard not to laugh...

At the end of the ride, the girlfriend apologized again for her boyfriend, and then handed me a twenty. The boyfriend gets out, and is suddenly very friendly with me, and asked his girlfriend if she had tipped me well. She replied that she did and both disappeared into their apartment building.

I thought this ride which started out sort of annoying, ended up very amusing and funny. The 20 dollar tip at the end was very nice.

Name: Mr.Do
Story:
I was doing some driving tonight, making pretty decent money when at about 9PM I got a phone call. Normally I have my calls screened so that if the number is not in my contact list it goes straight to voice mail, but I happened to have that switched that off because I was making some banking calls earlier in the day. I had a PAX in the car at the time so at first I ignored it, but then the call came again. So against my better judgement I answered. I am paraphrasing here a little bit but the person on the line said he was calling from Uber support and that since I was a stellar driver Uber was going to give me $500. I told him I had a fare and he said he would call back. 10 minutes later he did. He repeated his claim that he was going to give me $500. I parked the car and he proceeded to give my instructions on how to claim my cash. This involved changing the listed phone number in the app to one I did not know and then adding a debit card number to my cash out list. I went along with what he told me to do, but all the time I kept thinking something is not right. Before he could finish the process I hung up on him and tried to call Uber support. But of course it was in the evening and they are closed until Monday. Al the time the number came up again several times and then I got a text stating to call him back when I was ready to finish verification for my money. I am not going to do anything until I can verify this guy is who he says he is by calling Uber support Monday when they are open.

Was this a scam?? I don't know. But there is an old saying. "When something seems to be to good to be true, it probably is." Also, if you get a phone call in the middle of the night with a person wanting to give you money, alarm bells should be ringing.

I am pretty sure I almost lost a weeks worth of pay by cashing out to a strange debit card number. I am glad I wised up in time.

So this is a heads up to all drivers, there is some sort of scam targeting drivers out there. Beware of unknown calls offering you money.

Basically dead on the ride front. Anyways, as I’m sitting waiting for a ping I notice a guy in a nice suite slumped over on the corner of the sidewalk. People were passing by, and just stepping over him. Being in San Francisco there is homeless people and drug use everywhere so people are immune to this kind of stuff, but something was off. He had a suite on and looked different from the everyday bum. I told myself “don’t worry about it he’s just drunk” I was telling myself not to go over and check, but I’m looking at this dude not move and looking stone cold dead so I decided to get out of my car and go investigate. Well, turns out he’s alive, barely. I shake him awake and he’s moving and grumbling some nonsense. I call 911, which in San Francisco isn’t very useful. The operator on the line is asking me “sir is he breathing”. I’m trying to convey to her that he’s moving, but I think he’s just drunk or something. She says something that would ultimately cost him his life. She asked me “Sir do you want us to send an ambulance? We get a lot of these calls and if he seems ok maybe you can take him to a hospital if it’s safe for you” I was a bit surprised by that response. I was just asked to put him in my Lyft and drive him to the hospital. I end up rolling him over, he’s younger maybe 34, a good looking and clean cut Asian dude. I carry him to my car and sit him upright. He’s fumbling over, but I manage to strap him in my back seat. I start driving him to the nearest hospital ER. While we are driving I’m asking what his parents number is so I can let them know he’s in the hospital. He hands me his phone and after not unlocking it I’m forced to use his finger print to unlock it. I get in his phone and it’s all in a different language. I find a number he last texted in I message and copy it into my phone. I finish driving him to the hospital. I turn around and look at him and he’s dead. Like straight up eyes rolled back, dead. I run in to the ER heart pounding out of my chest thinking Jesus Christ I have a dead man in my car. The ER lady at the front desk hits the emergency button and a team of people rush out with a gurney and load him out of my car and wheel him into the ER. I don’t know what to text to the number, who it is or what I should say. I ended up saying “I found a man, and took him to the hospital, found your number in his phone” said my name and the hospital he was at and that was that. I get a call back a week later. It’s the person I texted. The man tells me the guy passed away from a drug overdose and mentioned he was his boyfriend and that the guy was depressed because he had just lost his law license and had a drug problem and they had just broken up. The boyfriend cried, but seemed almost relieved mentioning he had been a major burden on people. Like dang dude, he just died and your still gonna talk bad about him. Definitely a bad break up. It got weird after he offered to have my girlfriend and I have dinner at his restaurant for free for trying to save of his ex. He said this after he finished crying on the phone as I told him about the guys last moments. Anyways, this still haunts me to this day. Always get the ambulance if your unsure don’t let 911 convince you otherwise. 



End of story.

Name: Aw Jeez
Story:
Here in Pensacola, Florida, passengers often ask "how I did" during the worst of the pandemic lockdowns and such? They ask it in a concerned tone of voice, as if they assume I've done poorly. But I tell 'em, "Great!" The truth is that I did not miss a day of work, *and* I did not see any loss of business. I attribute this to two things:

1) There are plenty of people in my town who *had* to work - those employed by convenience stores and fast-food joints, nursing homes and restaurants...in other words, "essential" or exempted businesses. Many of my passengers were from a (ahem) lower-income strata of society and to work. But also, many of them did not have cars and have come to rely on R/S to get to and from work.



2) I assume that a lot of Uber/Lyft drivers are older, and many of them may have "health issues," otherwise, they'd all probably have regular jobs. My thinking goes that because many(?) R/S drivers fall into one or more "at-risk" category, they stopped driving out of, as they say on TV, "an abundance of caution." End result: Fewer drivers on the road competing for the rides.

Whatever the actual reasons, I did not have to stop driving nor did I lose any income at all in 2020. I hit all of my admittedly modest daily income targets, and I found that I could achieve them in fewer hours per day than in the pre-pandemic days. Most days, it was non-friggin' -stop...ping-ping-ping. I worked hard all my life; I did not take this "job" so I could work hard some more.. Sometimes I'd kind of feel guilty about stopping early and "abandoning" passengers who needed rides. But after my second beer, those feeling passed.

I know that my experience here in my town was probably not typical, but I hope that all of us who continued to drive through this (wink-wink) "pandemic" did as well.

I have a regular pax that I have driven to/from her work as well as a few other places over the past year. She lives in the housing projects, she is quiet and polite - most of the time. On a couple occasions I drove her together with a friend, and she was a different person; snippy and somewhat rude. Since I encounter other snippy and rude pax, this didn't really bother me. However, two incidents made this a problem. About a week ago I got a ping to pick her up a few blocks from her home. The address is a location where there have been a half dozen shootings in the past month, also public housing. I stopped on the street and carefully monitored my surroundings including the large parking lot of front of the apartment buildings that I assumed the pax would come from. I waited about two minutes and a young man approached across the grass, said "Lyft?" I answered "No." and got this in reply; "Then get your b.it.ch as.s out the street." I immediately obliged and left, canceled and got the fee. I got an immediate phone call from the pax; I told her what happened and she screamed; "That's my brother!" Too bad. 

This past Saturday night, I got a ping to pick her up at her workplace. When I arrived, after a couple minutes four young people, two girls and two boys (my regular was not one of them) came running out, laughing, all carrying several large bags from the closed store. I suspected they had just enjoyed a private no-charge shopping spree, but I'm not going to judge. They surrounded the car and began yelling, talking excitedly and yanking on my door handles. Only one was wearing a mask. I called out; "Sorry! Maximum three passengers. Masks required." This resulted in an immediate chorus of vociferous verbal abuse. (Flashback to a couple hundred traffic stops.) One maskless young man approached my door and pressed his body against my partially open window and proceeded to give me some serious hood eyes and attitude. I repeated the rules, realizing that he was very close to attacking me, called out "Watch your feet!" and pulled away quickly. As I did he threw a handful of something in my face, most bounced off the window but a couple hit me. (Throwing a "missile" at a moving car in Virginia is a felony.) The "missiles" turned out to be French fries, but I have gotten this offense charged before for rocks, gravel, a book, a bunch of keys, and an apple to name a few other "missiles." 

I went around the corner, canceled and got the fee. Called support, described the incident, they escalated to another team immediately and I described everything again to a very articulate, intelligent sounding support rep. Within half an hour I got an email saying that I would not be matched to this person again, and then a bit later another email adding that she had been banned from the platform. Satisfying, but I wonder how long that ban will last? Also, since I have taken several other pax to/ from this girl's workplace, chances are good that I'll see her again. That will be interesting. The most annoying part of this to me is that in spite of two dangerous incidents involving residents of the same housing projects, and in spite of multiple shootings in that location recently, I'm guessing that if a pax complains that I would not pick them up because of their race, I'll get deactivated. Do me a favor I suppose, but I do enjoy having this part time gig available. My cancelation rate is going to continue to climb

Name: Young Kim
Story:
So tonight (Sunday), I went out after tutoring a student in math... and got a ping that was twenty minutes away, by Lake Michigan. I was about to cancel but I got a phone call from the pax. I answered and there was a frantic voice on the other end:

(pax): "Please save us! We are stuck in the Chicago Botanical Gardens!, and we have a child in a stroller...and we are freezing!"

(me): "What is going on?!"

She explained that when the Chicago Botanical Gardens closed, she, her boyfriend, and her baby left thinking that they can easily get home. She tried to get an Uber and Lyft, but all cancelled... one after another after another. She had been out in the cold with her boyfriend and child for nearly an hour. She said they were freezing in the cold, and sounded totally desperate. She said her and her boyfriend's phone was about to die, and I was basically the last hope.

They saw some light show at the Botanical Gardens, and the place had closed a while back... I agreed to get them. I drove the twenty minutes from like west of Northfield to the gardens. When I got there, I saw that the entrance road INTO the gardens was closed! I called her and asked her where she was and that I could not get in.

She sounded increasingly frantic, and said there was no one there around them to ask, and it was so dark. I guess all the staff left, and they were all alone. She could not make out anything except that her boyfriend and baby and her were next to a big lit up Christmas tree. I then put my hazards on, and drove around until I saw an open road (but it was an "exit only") road. It was one way the wrong way... but I went anyway because it was private property, and there were no other cars anywhere, so I could see if there would be a car driving towards me...(e.g. I drove through one of the exit roads that led OUT of the gardens, and into the park.

I drove around for a bit looking for them, and she stayed on the phone while I drove. I could not see any lit up Christmas tree... The Chicago Botanical Gardens is HUGE, and finding a few people in the dark seemed hopeless. She said she and her boyfriend were getting completely panicked, because the boyfriend's phone was about to die, and hers was as well. I said I would continue to search, and said I would find help.

As I drove around for a while, I finally saw a car in the distance with a man wearing a shirt with those yellow florescent strips on it. I was so happy to see him, as there seemed to be NOBODY else in the park. I think it was around 11:00 pm at night. I drove right up and explained the situation. I put her on and she told him about the surroundings....

He immediately knew where it was, and said he would drive there and have me follow him. So I did...

About a minute later, we both saw them! and the baby stroller...

They ran up shivering. They both thanked me and the man who helped me find them. After getting in, she explained again how she requested and got cancelled on... again, and again, and again.

She said I was like a savior today (like a ER doctor, firefighter, or other rescue worker). She said that without me, they were about to completely panic, as they saw no other way to get home. I drove them about 20 minutes to Rogers Park, IL to their apartment. She told me her life story which was so interesting and full of adventure. She was 25 years old and inexperienced about life. She thanked me over and over again about my not cancelling on her, and how I was so great because I did not give up on her, her boyfriend, and her baby boy. She said that Christ answered her prayers today. She explained that she saw no other way of getting home if it were not for me.

When the ride ended, I showed her and her boyfriend a few magic tricks like this one that I thought the young child would like:


I am posting this feel good story because there was a moment like today where I felt really happy that I could help someone as an Uber driver. She made me feel like a hero!

Name: The Gift of Fish
Story:
A while back I did the Santander Uber lease (I know, I know). A year into the lease the car was totalled by another driver and, because he was underinsured, Uber's insurer at the time (James River) paid me the value of the car.

James River assessed the value of the car at $23,000 and Santander said the payoff amount (or the money still owed to them in the lease contract) was $21,000. James River said that they would send the settlement to Santander, whom they expected to deduct the payoff amount and send me the $2,000 balance.

When I got in touch with Santander to let them know what was happening, they claimed that, since the car belonged to them, they would be keeping the whole settlement from the insurer.

I responded that, although they owned the car, I owned the insurance policy and was the insured and beneficiary of it, not Santander. I told them that a lienholder is entitled to their financial interest in the asset; not a penny more or a penny less. However, Santander insisted that they would take all the money.

I called James River again. The said that Santander's position was highly unusual. They told me the same as I told Santander - I was the insured and was the one entitled to the settlement, less any lien balance due. They agreed to send Santander a check for the payoff amount and a separate check to me. The loss adjuster said that this was the first time he had ever had to do that. 

I phoned Santander to inform them that I had bypassed them, that they'd only be getting the $21,000 and that they should be grateful for it. I never heard from them again.

My question is: has anyone else ever come across such a scam attempt by Santander or other finance house when they have a lien on your car and your car is totalled out by an insurer for more than the payoff amount?
